data.name: CalculateFunctionInputText
data.value: The Calculate Service works like the function box in Microsoft Excel (fn). Type the equation using good maths practices and put a variable from the Data List into the Result field. You can use the full Excel library of functions eg. AVG([[Employee().Age]])

data.name: CalculateFunctionResultText
data.value: The variable you would like to contain the result once the calculation has completed.

data.name: CommentInputText
data.value: The comment entered here will not effect the workflow. This text will be visible in the debug output if this comment is included as a step in the workflow.

data.name: CountRecordsetFromRecordsetHelpText
data.value: Simply enter the name of the recordset that you want to count in. eg [[MyRecordset()]]

data.name: CountRecordsResultHelpText
data.value: Only variables in [[Scalar]] or [[Recordset(*).Field]] format. If you use a recordset and do not specify an index/row number, a new record will be added.

data.name: DateTimeAddTimeHelpText
data.value: Put a positive or negative number here to add or subtract from the input date time. Leave this field blank if you do not want to change the date time.

data.name: DateTimeInputFormatHelpText
data.value: Describe the format of the date time you are entering. e.g. 23-July 1978 would be described as dd-MM yyyy. Leaving this field blank will assume the system date time format.

data.name: DateTimeInputHelpText
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To format a date time, or to add/subtract from a date time, put it in here. Leaving this field blank will give you the system date time.

data.name: DateTimeOutputFormatHelpText
data.value: Describe the format you would like the date time to be returned in. Leaving this field blank will assume the same as the Input Format.

data.name: DateTimeResultHelpText
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the formatted and/or added/subtracted date time. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: FindRecordsFieldsToSearchHelpText
data.value: To find the indexes/rows that match certain criteria, put the comma separated list of fields to search in here. e.g. [[Customer().Name]], [[Customer().Prename]], [[Customer().Surname]]

data.name: FindRecordsSearchTypeHelpText
data.value: Select the type of information you want to match on.

data.name: FindRecordsMatchHelpText
data.value: Select the match data to find.

data.name: FindRecordsResultHelpText
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the indexes of the successful matches. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record. If there are multiple results and a scalar is used, then each result will be separated with a comma.

data.name: MultiAssignNewValueHelpText
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To assign a value to a variable, put the value in here. If you put an = as the first character, it will turn into a calculation e.g. =[[qty]]*[[price]]

data.name: MultiAssignVariableHelpText
data.value: Only variables go in here. To assign a value to a variable, put the variable here. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: DataSplitHelpProcessDirection
data.value: Default direction to process is forward or left to right (reading direction). Selecting Backwards will process from the end of the data (right) to the beginning (left).

data.name: BaseConvertResultHelpText
data.value: The variable where the result will be output to.

data.name: BaseConvertInputHelpText
data.value: This data must be in the format specified in the 'Convert From' category. This data will be converted to the format specified in the 'Convert To' column.

data.name: QuickVariableAppendHelpText
data.value: Append will add the variables onto the list of variables already in the input grid. The values of the last row will be repeated for all of these additional values.

data.name: QuickVariablePrefixWithHelpText
data.value: To append something onto the front of the variables in your list, type it in here. For recordsets, type recordsetname(). Dont forget the "." after the "()" You do not need to put the "[[" in.

data.name: QuickVariableSplitAndAtHelpText
data.value: Select the criteria to split the variables in the list. This will be the pattern used to repeat against the Variable List box. Char will split on the characters you specify, like comma or | </. Index will split on the numeric index from the previouse split. New Line will split on carriage return. Space will split on blank space. Tab splits on a tab character.

data.name: QuickVariableSplitListOnHelpText
data.value: Simply enter the name of the recordset that you want to count in. eg [[MyRecordset()]]

data.name: QuickVariableSuffixWithHelpText
data.value: To append something onto the end of the variables in your list, type it in here. You do not need to put the "]]" in.

data.name: QuickVariableVariableListHelpText
data.value: Type or paste all the variables you want to use in here. You can paste in any format. If you are adding variables into a grid with a drop down or other input, the values from the last row will be repeated, so set them before adding these variables.

data.name: QuickVariableReplaceHelpText
data.value: Replace will replace the current list of variables with this list. The values of the first row will be repeated for all of these new values.

data.name: PreviewInputHelpText
data.value:
Preview (recordset field) This is a variable from an input field. Use comma-separated values for each index eg [[Trip(*).Distance]] = 45, 32, 12, 5
Preview (scalar field - including indexed recordsets and ()) This is a variable from an input field. Put some test info in and click the Preview button to test your result.

data.name: WebRequestHeaderHelpText
data.value: To supply additional header information in your get request, put the header info in here.

data.name: WebRequestResultHelpText
data.value: Only a single variable goes in here. Returnes the response text of the web get request.

data.name: WebRequestURIHelpText
data.value: Any data or variable can go in here. To traverse an retrieve the raw response from a webpage, enter it in here.

data.name: DateTimeAddTimeTypeHelpText
data.value: Select the unit of time to add or subtract. This is ignored if the unit is blank or 0.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertHelpInputColumn
data.value: To bulk insert data into a table, put the data to insert in here. Using recordset (*) notation will put the entire recordset in and is the normal usage scenario for large data inserts to SQL. A single Recordset will yield the best performance. Do not mix, scalars and/or different recordsets for optimum performance. To quickly change the input data, press the Quick Variable Input button and ammend the mappings as necessary.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns Success or the record numbers with errors. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertHelpBatchSize
data.value: The number of rows you would like to insert at a time. The default is 0 which will do everything in 1 batch. If you specify 50, then 50 rows will be bulk inserted at a time.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertHelpCheckConstraints
data.value: Check constraints while data is being inserted. By default, constraints are not checked.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertHelpDatabase
data.value: Select a preconfigured database source or "New Database Source..." to add a new one.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertHelpFireTriggers
data.value: When specified, cause the server to fire the insert triggers for the rows being inserted into the database.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertHelpKeepIdentity
data.value: Preserve source identity values. When not specified, identity values are assigned by the destination.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertHelpKeepTableLock
data.value: Obtain a bulk update lock for the duration of the bulk copy operation. When not specified, row locks are used.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertHelpTableName
data.value: Select a table to perform the bulk insert into. If the table schema has changed or recently added to the source, click the refresh button.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertHelpTimeout
data.value: The number of seconds you would like the operation to complete in. All batches in total must complete within this time period. The default is 0 which will be no time constraint. If you specify 30, then 30 seconds will be allowed for the entire operation to complete before timing out. Note, the timeout is purely for the actual SQL connection and not the preparation of the data to be inserted.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertHelpUseInternalTransaction
data.value: When specified, each batch of the bulk-copy operation will occur within a transaction.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipBatchSize
data.value: Number [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipCheckConstraints
data.value: Check constraints while data is being inserted.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipDatabase
data.value: Select a preconfigured database source or "New Database Source..." to add a new one.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipFireTriggers
data.value: When specified, cause the server to fire the insert triggers for the rows being inserted into the database.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipInputColumn
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipKeepIdentity
data.value: Preserve source identity values.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipKeepTableLock
data.value: Obtain a bulk update lock for the duration of the bulk copy operation.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipTableName
data.value: Select a table to perform the bulk insert into.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipTimeout
data.value: Number [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipUseInternalTransaction
data.value: When specified, each batch of the bulk-copy operation will occur within a transaction.

data.name: String
data.value: To bulk insert data into a table, put the data to insert in here.

data.name: String1
data.value: Using recordset (*) notation will put the entire recordset in and is the normal usage scenario for large data inserts to SQL.

data.name: String2
data.value: NOTE: A single Recordset will yield the best performance. Do not mix, scalars and/or different recordsets for optimum performance.

data.name: OnErrorHelpIsEnded
data.value: To end the workflow if an error has occurred at this point, make sure the checkbox is selected. If you have also called a web service / Warewolf workflow, that will finish executing first. If the workflow is nested, the calling workflow will resume.

data.name: OnErrorHelpVariable
data.value: If an error occurs the error message will be placed into this variable as well the result variable. If left empty the result will still be placed in the result variable.

data.name: OnErrorHelpWorkflow
data.value: If an error occurs you can execute a web service / Warewolf workflow to log the error that occurred. E.g. http://ServerName:77/Services/LogErrors?Severity=1&Error=[[ErrorMsg]]

data.name: OnErrorToolTipIsEnded
data.value: Ends the executing workflow at this point

data.name: OnErrorToolTipVariable
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: OnErrorToolTipWorkflow
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: SortRecordsHelpSortField
data.value: To Sort a recordset enter the field in the recordset you would like to sort on. To sort on more than one field, perform the sort action for each field you would like to sort on, ending with the priority sort.

data.name: SortRecordsHelpSortOrderType
data.value: Select the order of the sorting. Forward will go 1-9 then a-Z. Backward will go Z-a then 9-1.

data.name: SortRecordsToolTipSortField
data.value: [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: BaseConversionHelpBaseInput
data.value: Any variable and data goes in here. To convert Text, Hex, Binary and Base64, put the data to be converted in here.

data.name: BaseConversionHelpFromType
data.value: Select the type of data you are converting from. e.g. If the data is Binary and you would like Text, then select Binary here.

data.name: BaseConversionHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the converted data into a separate variable. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: BaseConversionHelpToType
data.value: Select the type of data you are converting to. e.g. If the data is Binary and you would like Text, then select Text here.

data.name: BaseConversionToolTipBaseInput
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: BaseConversionToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CaseConversionHelpConvertToCaseType
data.value: Select the type of conversion you would like to make.

data.name: CaseConversionHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the converted data. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: CaseConversionHelpTextInput
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To convert the case of some text, put the variable containing the text here.

data.name: CaseConversionToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CaseConversionToolTipTextInput
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CopyHelpDestination
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. Put the full path of the destination you are copying to here. You can use File System, URI, SFTP, FTP or FTPS format.

data.name: CopyHelpFileFolder
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To copy a file or folder, put the full path and file or folder name here. You can use File System, URI, SFTP, FTP or FTPS format.

data.name: CopyHelpSourcePassword
data.value: For protected resources, specify the Password of an account with permission to access the source. By default the account running Warewolf Server.exe service will be used.

data.name: CopyHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns Success or will be blank depending on the success of the Copy action. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: CopyHelpSourceUsername
data.value: For protected resources, specify the Username of an account with permission to access the source. By default the account running Warewolf Server.exe service will be used.

data.name: CopyToolHelpForceOverwrite
data.value: If the file or folder already exists, you can force a new one to overwrite the old one.

data.name: CopyToolTipDestination
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CopyToolTipFileFolder
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CopyToolTipForceOverwrite
data.value: If it exists already, force an overwrite

data.name: CopyToolTipPassword
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CopyToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CopyToolTipUsername
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CreateHelpFileFolder
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To create a file or folder, put the full path and file or folder name here. You can use File System, URI, SFTP, FTP or FTPS format.

data.name: CreateHelpForceOverWrite
data.value: If the file or folder already exists, you can force a new one to overwrite the old one.

data.name: CreateHelpPassword
data.value: For protected resources, specify the Password of an account with permission to perform this action. By default the account running Warewolf Server.exe service will be used.

data.name: CreateHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns Success or will be blank depending on the success of the Create action. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: CreateHelpUsername
data.value: For protected resources, specify the Username of an account with permission to perform this action. By default the account running Warewolf Server.exe service will be used.

data.name: CreateToolTipFileFolder
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CreateToolTipForceOverWrite
data.value: If it exists already, force an overwrite

data.name: CreateToolTipPassword
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CreateToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CreateToolTipUsername
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: DataMergeHelpAlignType
data.value: For Index you can specify if your data is aligned to the right or left. E.g. Text is normally left and numbers normally right.

data.name: DataMergeHelpInput
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To join two or more pieces of data together list them in the order you would like them joined. If you use recordset (*) notation, the list will be repeated for every record.

data.name: DataMergeHelpPadding
data.value: If Index is being used and there is extra space between the data supplied and the number of index characters, you can specify what makes up the padding e.g. 0 for numbers or blank space for text.

data.name: DataMergeHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the merged string. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: DataMergeHelpUsing
data.value: For Index use the number of characters that this merge will use. It will either trim if too little, or pad if too much. For Char put any characters or combination of characters you would like. Not applicable to New Line or Tab

data.name: DataMergeHelpWithType
data.value: Select the type of merge you would like between each piece of merged data, if any.

data.name: DataMergeToolTipInput
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: DataMergeToolTipPadding
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: DataMergeToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: DataMergeToolTipUsing
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: DataSplitHelpEscape
data.value: If there is an occurrence or an item being split on, that should not be split on, it will be preceded with this character. e.g., a comma separated file might have a comma in a name, so don’t split on it if it is preceded by / or some other characters.

data.name: DataSplitHelpInclude
data.value: If you would like the data or item you are splitting on to be included in the result data, select this checkbox.

data.name: DataSplitHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the split data in the pattern as described by the results. The variable pattern will be repeated until the end of the input data. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: DataSplitHelpString
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To split a value into one or more variables, put the value in here. You can process entire file content or just trim the white space from a variable.

data.name: DataSplitHelpUsing
data.value: For Index use the number of characters that this split will use. For Char put any characters or combination of characters you would like. Not applicable to New Line, Tab or End

data.name: DataSplitHelpWithType
data.value: Select where you would like to split the data.

data.name: DataSplitToolTipEscape
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: DataSplitToolTipInclude
data.value: Include the information you are splitting on?

data.name: DataSplitToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: DataSplitToolTipString
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: DataSplitToolTipUsing
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: FindIndexHelpCharacters
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. Put the index of the string you are looking for in here.

data.name: FindIndexHelpDirectiontype
data.value: Select the direction to search in.

data.name: FindIndexHelpIndexType
data.value: Select which index(es) you would like found.

data.name: FindIndexHelpInField
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To find the character index(es) of a string inside another string, put the string to be searched here.

data.name: FindIndexHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the index(es) of the found string. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record. If you are finding All Occurrences and using a scalar, the results will be comma separated.

data.name: FindIndexToolTipCharacters
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: FindIndexToolTipInField
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: FindIndexToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: ReplaceHelpFind
data.value: Put the information you are looking for in here.

data.name: ReplaceHelpInField
data.value: Only variables go in here. To search and replace a string, put the variable containing the string to search in here.

data.name: ReplaceHelpReplaceWith
data.value: Put the replacement information in here.

data.name: ReplaceHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the count of the number of replacements. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: ReplaceToolTipFind
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: ReplaceToolTipInField
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: ReplaceToolTipReplaceWith
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: ReplaceToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CountRecordsHelpRecordset
data.value: To Count the number of records/indexes in a recordset, put the recordset name in here. E.g. [[Customer()]]

data.name: CountRecordsHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns a number specifying how many records/indexes are in the recordset. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: CountRecordsToolTipRecordset
data.value: [[Recordset()]]

data.name: CountRecordsToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: DeleteRecordsHelpRecords
data.value: To Delete a record in a recordset, put the recordset name in here with the index you would like to remove. e.g. [[Customers(7)]] will remove the record at index 7. [[Customers(*)]] will delete all the data in the recordset. This is recommended when working with large amounts of data that is no longer needed.

data.name: DeleteRecordsHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the Success or Failure of the delete action. e.g. Deleting index 8 where it does not exist will result in Failure. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: DeleteRecordsToolTipRecords
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: DeleteRecordsToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: UniqueRecordsHelpInField
data.value: To identify unique information in a recordset, put the comma separated fields that need to be unique in here.

data.name: UniqueRecordsHelpResult
data.value: Returns the unique combinations into the variables specified. If there are multiple fields being returned, there should be multiple Results fields specified. Use a comma to separate the variables.

data.name: UniqueRecordsHelpReturnField
data.value: Which fields from the recordset would you like returned when a Unique combination is found? Use a comma separated list of the fields. Where multiple rows are the same, the first one will be deemed Unique.

data.name: UniqueRecordsToolTipInField
data.value: [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: UniqueRecordsToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: UniqueRecordsToolTipReturnField
data.value: [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CalculateHelpFx
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To perform a calculation, put the calculation in here in BODMAS format. There are many supporting functions like average() and sum() that can be used with recordsets e.g. Sum([[staff(*).salaries]]) will sum all the salaries fields of the staff recordset.

data.name: CalculateHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the formatted number. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: CalculateToolTipFx
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: CalculateToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: FormatNumberHelpDecimalToShow
data.value: How many decimals should be returned as a factor of 10? e.g. 3 will show 0.000 and negative 3 (-3) will show 15000 as 15.

data.name: FormatNumberHelpNumber
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To format a number, put the number in here.

data.name: FormatNumberHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the formatted number. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: FormatNumberHelpRoundType
data.value: How would you like to round the number? None: No rounding is done Normal: 5,6,7,8,9 round up & 1,2,3,4 round down Up: 1-9 all round up Down: 1-9 all round down

data.name: FormatNumberHelpRoundValue
data.value: At what point in the number should the rounding be done as a factor of 10? e.g. 3 will round to 3 decimal places and negative 3 (-3) will round to the nearest thousand.

data.name: FormatNumberToolTipDecimalToShow
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: FormatNumberToolTipNumber
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: FormatNumberToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: FormatNumberToolTipRoundvalue
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: ServiceHelpInput
data.value: Insert the input data for this service. It will be mapped to the input field listed in the To Service column. If the input is a Recordset field then you can use (*) to pass all the recordset fields into the workflow service. e.g. [[my(*).recs]] -> input().records You can also put multiple fields into one field with other text much like the assign tool. By default similar matches from the variable list are used where possible.

data.name: ServiceHelpOutput
data.value: Only variables go in here. Insert the variable that you want the output of the workflow to be mapped into. By default similar matches from the variable list are used where possible. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: ServiceToolTipInput
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: ServiceToolTipOutput
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: MoveHelpDestination
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. Put the full path of the destination you are moving to here. You can use File System, URI, SFTP, FTP or FTPS format.

data.name: MoveHelpFileFolder

data.name: ZipHelpCompressionType
data.value: The system will try and match your zipping requirements as far as possible. None creates the new file with the content and adds no compression - fastest. Partial attempts some compression. Normal will apply standard compression. Max will compress the zipped file as much as possible - slowest.

data.name: CommandLineHelpCMD
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To execute a command line action or actions, enter them in here. Acts like a batch file. Any user driven task will simply be ignored.

data.name: CommandLineHelpPriorityType
data.value: The process priority for execution. Very helpful for long running processes that need/don’t need to be resource intensive.

data.name: CommandLineHelpResult
data.value: Returns the output of the execution if any. Varies depending on what was executed.

data.name: CommentHelpComment
data.value: Comments do not execute and are place holders for fututre services or tools or simply to leave commenty inside the workflow. You can connect comments into the process flow and they will simply be skipped during execution. However, they will appear in the debug output.

data.name: CommentToolTipComment
data.value: Notes and comments will not be executed at run time but will show up in the debug output.

data.name: DateTimeDifferenceHelpDateTime1
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To find the difference in time between two date times, put the first date time in here. The format needs to be the same for the two. Leaving this field blank will give you the system date time.

data.name: DateTimeDifferenceHelpDateTime2
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To find the difference in time between two date times, put the second date time in here. The format needs to be the same for the two. Leaving this field blank will give you the system date time.

data.name: DateTimeDifferenceHelpInputFormat
data.value: Describe the format of the date times you are entering. e.g. 23-July 1978 would be described as dd-MM yyyy. Leaving this field blank will assume the system date time format.

data.name: DateTimeDifferenceHelpOutputType
data.value: Select the unit of time to output the difference in.

data.name: DateTimeDifferenceHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the difference in time between the two date times. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.value: List the email addresses you want to blind carbon copy on the email you are sending separated by a semicolon ; If you are on a domain, you still need to provide the email address of the account you are sending to.

data.value: List the email addresses you want to carbon copy on the email you are sending separated by a semicolon ; If you are on a domain, you still need to provide the email address of the account you are sending to.

data.name: RandomHelpRangeTo

data.name: ForEachHelpForEachType
data.value: Replaces the * in the activity with the relevant index. e.g. If 1-3 is provided then [[Customer(*).ID]] will execute as [[Customer(1).ID]], [[Customer(2).ID]], [[Customer(3).ID]]. * in Range allows you to input a range of indexes. * in CSV allows a specific set of indexes to be specified e.g. 1,5,7,9. * in Recordset will execute every index in the given recordset. No. of executions will execute the activity a given number of times.

data.name: ForEachHelpValue
data.value: Replaces the * in the activity with the relevant index. e.g. If 1-3 is provided then [[Customer(*).ID]] will execute as [[Customer(1).ID]], [[Customer(2).ID]], [[Customer(3).ID]]. * in Range allows you to input a range of indexes. * in CSV allows a specific set of indexes to be specified e.g. 1,5,7,9. * in Recordset will execute every index in the given recordset. No. of executions will execute the activity a given number of times.

data.name: ForEachToolTipValue
data.value: Data [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]

Each Xpath expression returned will be added to the result recordset in a new record or comma separated list if a scalar variable is defined.

data.name: FindRecordsFromHelpText

data.value: Should each criteria be met?

data.name: SchedulerSettingsHelpTextHistoryRecords
data.value: To prevent redundant data being kept the system will clean up old schedule results. To specify how many results to keep, put a whole number in here.

data.name: SchedulerSettingsHelpTextName
data.value: The name of the schedule that will appear in the list of Schedules in the left hand column. Renaming a Schedule will loose its History.

data.name: SchedulerSettingsHelpTextPassword
data.value: Each workflow must be executed with the correct security context. The account details entered here will be passed to the server and execute the workflow as that user.

data.name: SchedulerSettingsHelpTextRun
data.value: Check this box if you would like a missed trigger to execute as soon as possible.

data.name: SchedulerSettingsHelpTextStatus
data.value: To change if the trigger is active or not, select Enabled or Dissabled.

data.name: SchedulerSettingsHelpTextTrigger
data.value: To run a workflow on a schedule select the Edit Trigger button.

data.name: SchedulerSettingsHelpTextUsername
data.value: Each workflow must be executed with the correct security context. The account details entered here will be passed to the server and execute the workflow as that user.

data.name: SchedulerSettingsHelpTextWorkFlow
data.value: To run a workflow on a schedule select the Trigger above and then click … to choose the workflow you want to execute.

data.name: SchedulerSettingsToolTipHistoryRecords
data.value: How much History should the system keep?

data.name: SchedulerSettingsToolTipName
data.value: What name do you want to give this Schedule?

data.name: SchedulerSettingsToolTipPassword
data.value: Schedule will use this password for the above username

data.name: SchedulerSettingsToolTipRun
data.value: Allows a missed trigger to be executed

data.name: SchedulerSettingsToolTipTrigger
data.value: When should the workflow run?

data.name: SchedulerSettingsToolTipUsername
data.value: Schedule should execute as this user

data.name: SchedulerSettingsToolTipWorkFlow
data.value: Select a workflow to be triggered

data.name: SchedulerSettingsHelpTextHistoryView
data.value: Each trigger that is executed will be stored in the system. To see the result of the workflow execution, select the history record and then look at the Output pane.

data.name: RecordsLengthHelpRecordset
data.value: To get the length or max index in a recordset, put the recordset name in here. E.g. [[Customer()]]

data.name: RecordsLengthHelpResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns a number specifying the highest index / max index in the recordset.

data.name: RecordsLengthToolTipRecordset
data.value: [[Recordset()]]

data.name: RecordsLengthToolTipResult
data.value: [[Scalar]] [[Recordset(n).Field]] [[Recordset(*).Field]] [[Recordset().Field]]
